Each and every day it is my honor to serve the people of California as their United States Senator. Today, I have the distinct honor of making it “Facebook official” by launching my official Senate Facebook account.
I rise today humbled to offer my first official speech as the junior United States Senator from the great State of California.

For me, it starts with my mother Shyamala Harris. She arrived at the University of California Berkeley from India in 1959 with dreams of becoming a scientist. The plan, when she finished school, was to go back home to a traditional Indian marriage. But when she met my father Donald Harris, she made a different plan. She went against a practice reaching back thousands of years, and instead of an arranged marriage, chose a love marriage. This, an act of self-determination, made me and my sister Maya. And - like millions of the children of immigrants before and since - it made us Americans.

Meet Yuriana, she’ll join me tomorrow when Pres. Trump addresses Congress:   “For me, there are certainly fears. I fear that I’ll be in the flea market one day they will be rounding people up for deportations. I fear that no one is going to care that I have a PhD or that I have lived in the United States for as long as I can remember. I was born in Apatzingan, Mexico, but Fresno is my home. My parents and I moved there before I started kindergarten. None of us had immigration papers. When I was growing up, my parents always told me that ‘no one can take away your education. The government may not give you papers, but they can’t take away your learning.’   There have been a lot of obstacles to getting to where I am now. When I went to college, I wasn’t eligible for the financial aid and scholarships other students were because of my status. It was very discouraging. When I graduated, I knew I wanted to pursue my PhD, but I didn’t qualify for work study programs for the same reason. I couldn’t bear to give up research, so for a full year after I graduated I worked in the lab for free.   I’ll never forget the day I heard the news about DACA. I was in the lab and I cried. It was emotional - knowing that I would actually be able to continue to work there, continue to do what I love. As soon as I was able, I applied to the University of California-Merced, where I graduated with a PhD from the Quantitative Systems Biology Program. I hope to one day have my own research lab where I can study sudden cardiac arrest syndrome.   The best part about my work?... Science doesn’t have borders, there are no limitations on its advancement.”

My guest for President Trump’s Joint Session speech yesterday was Yuriana. She is one of the more than 250,000 Californians brought to the United States as children. People at home, in Washington and even here on my Facebook page all voiced concerns for her safety. It took a lot of bravery for her to walk into that room last night. What’s even more remarkable - she walked into that room with a sense of optimism. She’s familiar with that fear. She and 250,000 other Californians worry every day that they or one of their family members might get picked up at the bus stop or grocery store. Last night, she hoped that President Trump would offer her and her husband a promise, some certainty - but he did nothing to assuage her fears.

Attorney General Sessions deceived Congress and the American people, irreparably damaging his integrity, and is therefore ineligible to serve as the top law enforcement official of our country. He must resign immediately. In sworn testimony, Sessions said he had not communicated with Russian officials at a time when Russia was actively interfering with our election and he was serving as an official advisor to the Trump campaign. It is now clear that was a lie.      Weeks ago, I said Attorney General Sessions could not be an impartial steward of the FBI’s investigation into communication and ties between the Russians and President Trump's campaign given his formal role on the campaign. But his recusal is no longer enough.      The faith Americans have in both a fair election and their elected officials has been fundamentally damaged and cannot be restored until there's a full accounting of the facts. This is critical to combating future Russian intrusion in our government and electoral process. Attorney General Sessions is a roadblock to that goal. It is essential to doing the work of justice that the American people believe that the top prosecutor is honest and unbiased. In the best interest of the nation, Attorney General Sessions must vacate his position immediately.

In most cases, the United States is the only country they know as home. They have played by the rules. Participating in the DACA means you place trust in our government by filing paperwork with your personal identification information. That’s a scary thing if you are undocumented and fear deportation. It’s a big risk to come out of the shadows. But our government has promised that in exchange for giving them your information and paying a sizeable fee, they won’t be deported and the information they provided about themselves and their families won’t be turned over to ICE. The government then vets you. Upon determining you have lived a lawful and productive life, you’ll receive “DACA status,” meaning you can live and work here or keep going to school here. DACA does not provide you a path to citizenship. Now, the Trump Administration has changed the rules on these kids. First, Trump has decided to end the DACA program. We are all still shocked and saddened by the devastation caused by the massive wildfires that have swept across our state in the last several days. More than 40 Californians have lost their lives. I’m committed to doing everything in my power to make sure this never happens again. Every second of warning is crucial to escaping a fast-moving wildfire. In emergencies like these, the federal Wireless Emergency Alert (WEA) system has the potential to be a helpful tool. It is designed to send buzz alerts, including evacuation orders and safety information, to your cellphone free-of-charge. However, it has become apparent that during the wildfires many Californians in harm’s way didn’t receive emergency alerts. This tool was not able to be used effectively, in part, because the messages could not be geotargeted. Local authorities need the ability to send alerts specifically to residents in certain areas, not just everyone in the county. This is technologically possible - the hang up is a rule that needs to be implemented by the FCC. So, today Senator Feinstein and I contacted the Chairman of the FCC to find out why this isn’t happening. We’re going to keep pushing on this. It’s a straightforward upgrade to our national emergency infrastructure that can help communities everywhere in the country when disaster strikes.

Sexual harassment and misconduct should not be allowed by anyone and should not occur anywhere. I believe the best thing is for Senator Franken to step down.   However, this conversation does not begin or end with any one individual. It is clear that Congress needs a fundamental overhaul in how we deal with sexual harassment and assault. The process is too slow and too murky. What we need is swift action and transparency.   We also need to take a look at this across all industries and all professions. I am equally concerned about the waitresses, domestic workers, and women working on factory lines who have come forward to share their experiences with harassment and violence. If today is the end of this conversation, then we will have failed not only those women working now, not only the courageous women who have come forward, but the next generation of women who will enter the workplace.   I will continue to work with my colleagues on efforts to address the issue of sexual assault and misconduct in Congress or anywhere else.

“I came to the United States from Guatemala when I was 9 years old, but I didn’t find out I was undocumented until I was 17 and ready to go to college. With a 4.0 in hand, I was preparing to apply to California’s top schools but as I was going through the process, I found out that I didn’t have a social security number. It hit me like a bat to realize that even if I graduated from college, I couldn’t work as a professional.   “I took a leap of faith and went to college anyway. Often I would wonder if going to college was the right decision but I knew that I loved learning and I loved going to school. When I found out about DACA, I was so happy to be able to do the little things, like check out books from the local library with my new ID. Knowing that the administration somehow understood my situation even though they didn’t know me personally was an incredible feeling. Today, I have a Master’s degree in Nonprofit Leadership and Management from the University of Southern California.   “I’m very proud of the work that I do as the Statewide Youth Organizer for CHIRLA’s California Dream Network. I get to train other young people to rise up as organizers and to be a voice for immigrants and young people who are undocumented. I want undocumented young immigrants everywhere to know that I am here for them and that they are not alone. We’ve come so far and this is not the time to go back into the shadows.” – Melody

Today marks five years since twenty six-and-seven-year-old children, and six of their teachers lost their lives at Sandy Hook Elementary School. This kind of unimaginable tragedy has become routine in America, and we are weary. We are saddened, but no longer shocked. Last week, I met with three survivors of the Las Vegas shooting, and one of the women said to me, “I just don’t understand why more isn’t getting done.” She’s right. The idea that days, months, and years can go by with no action is not right. It’s unreasonable, and it doesn’t make sense. We can’t simply throw up our hands or continue to justify the presence of weapons of war whose primary purpose is to kill the largest number of human beings in the shortest amount of time possible. There’s no question that this is an uphill battle, but I believe another moment of silence simply won’t suffice. We need to take action. It is the only way to honor the lives of those lost, and prevent future tragedies.

“I came to the United States from El Salvador when I was 5 years old, and I remember feeling so happy to see both of my parents for the first time since I could remember. Growing up undocumented, I always felt pressured to do really well in school and in my community. I eventually isolated myself, not because I wanted to but because of the pressure I felt to not make a single mistake or do anything wrong.  “When I found out about DACA, I knew that it was the right and lawful thing to do. I submitted to the government every aspect of my life – where I lived, where I studied, everything. I now feel betrayed, as if my country that I so dearly love doesn’t want me. I want people to judge me for the person I am and not on the fact that I don’t have a piece of paper that says I belong here. I’m pursuing an education and doing my best to help my community. I’m the youngest Rotarian in Placer County and am also a Placer County Youth Commissioner, which means I get to work with the Board of Supervisors and represent the youth in my community. I also recently co-founded California Dreamers, where we do community service and empower our youth to speak out about what they believe is right.” -Doris

The tax plan approved by my Republican colleagues in the House and Senate last night is a gift to corporations and the top 1% at the expense of middle-class families. At a time when wages have stagnated and working Americans are trying to do more with less, this tax plan pulls the rug out from the middle class to give billions to those who already have so much. This is an attack on our values, and Americans deserve better.   Instead of a real middle-class tax cut, 83% of the benefits of this bill go to the top 1% over the next decade. While corporate profits are at an all-time high, this plan permanently lowers the corporate tax rate and increases taxes on 57% of middle-class Americans over the next decade. Many California families will see a tax increase as a result of changes to the state and local tax deduction. And while millions of Americans are only one trip to the emergency room away from bankruptcy, Republicans have just voted to eliminate the individual mandate and leave 13 million more Americans uninsured over the next decade.   If we really want to help working Americans, then let’s take up causes that would actually put money into their hands, like raising the minimum wage, making public colleges and universities tuition-free, and guaranteeing access to health care for everyone. There are far better ways to deliver to the American people, and I remain committed to fighting for them.

Russia attacked the very heart of our democracy in the 2016 election. They launched an unprecedented hacking campaign against our country’s election infrastructure. We must act now to fortify our election systems against attacks by foreign powers. Today, I’ve introduced the Secure Elections Act, a bill that would improve cybersecurity information sharing between federal and state agencies, ensure state election officials have timely access to classified material, establish expert guidelines for securing election systems, provide grants for both long-term and immediate cybersecurity improvements, encourage effective post-election auditing, and establish a bug bounty program for election infrastructure. We need to make smart, comprehensive improvements to our election security and we need to do it fast.

It’s critical that we fund our government—but when we do, we must be sure to fund all of the priorities that are crucial to Californians and the middle-class. With the short-term and short-sighted spending bill Republicans passed tonight, this Congress has said loud and clear that Dreamers, children, and families devastated by wildfires can wait—but corporate tax cuts can’t. I do not accept that. And I will continue to fight for a spending bill that puts hard-working Americans first.
